profile_data.summary:
üéì Education and Academic Achievements:
Enthusiastic Program and Product Manager, currently working full-time while pursuing an MBA at NYU Stern, seamlessly blending practical experience with academic rigor. Holds graduate certificate in #ManagementScienceEngineering from Stanford, a #ProjectManagement Certification from Cornell, and dual degrees in #MaterialsScienceEngineering. This unique blend equips me with a holistic approach to management, business, engineering, and data, fostering a well-rounded perspective.

üöÄ Professional Experience and Achievements:
Experienced in dynamically managing 30 concurrent bioanalytical projects, employing cutting-edge tools such as #Mondaydotcom and harnessing data analysis prowess with #RProgramming. Achieved a stellar 95% on-time project rate, translating to a $4 million in annual revenue. Instrumental in realizing a 15% boost in client satisfaction, a 10% reduction in project delivery time, and a notable 30% increase in resource utilization. Pioneered the implementation of an advanced #LIMS system, powered by R, resulting in a substantial 42% improvement in operational efficiency and an impressive 25% reduction in costs.

üåü Career Goals and Future Plans:
Passionately pursuing a mission to seamlessly blend Program and Product Management skills, utilizing data-driven strategies to ensure project excellence. My ongoing academic journey at NYU reflects my commitment to staying at the forefront of industry innovation. My aim is to contribute significantly to the field, fostering innovation and creating a lasting impact. Eager to collaborate with forward-thinking professionals and organizations to drive mutual growth and success.

#ProgramManagement #ProductManagement #DataAnalysis #InnovationLeadership #BioanalyticalProjects #CareerGoals

projects.description:
I‚Äôm thrilled to share my latest project where I combined the power of Machine Learning and Financial Data Analysis to predict credit card default risk. This journey has been both exciting and rewarding as I explored the intersection of technology and real-world financial challenges. Here's a quick rundown:

üîç The Challenge:
How can we predict the likelihood of a credit card holder defaulting on their payment? Accurately identifying risk is critical for financial institutions to design better credit policies and manage portfolios effectively.

üìà The Approach:

Conducted extensive Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) to uncover patterns in features like payment history, credit limits, and outstanding balances.
Built and fine-tuned a RandomForestClassifier üå≥, which emerged as the best-performing model with an accuracy of 85%! üéØ
Optimized the model using RandomizedSearchCV to deliver actionable insights.
‚ú® Key Insights:

Payment history features (e.g., past payment trends) were the most critical indicators of default risk.
Features like credit limit and bill amounts also played a significant role in predictions.
The results align with real-world practices, reinforcing how banks evaluate customer credit risk.
üíº Industry Relevance:
This project demonstrates how machine learning models like Random Forest can assist financial institutions in mitigating risks, optimizing credit strategies, and improving profitability through data-driven decisions.

üîó Check out the full project on GitHub to explore the journey from data to insights!
https://github.com/29nasa/Credit_Card_Default

üåü I'm excited about how projects like this can contribute to innovating financial decision-making. If you're working on similar projects or have ideas to share, let‚Äôs connect and exchange thoughts! ü§ù

#MachineLearning #DataScience #CreditRisk #AI #Finance #RandomForest #Innovation
projects.title: üöÄ Credit Card Default Risk Prediction: Unlocking Insights with Machine Learning! #FinTech üí≥üìä

member.occupation: MSQM @ NYU Stern | GC MS&E @ Stanford | Ex-Engineer @ Schlumberger (SLB) | PMO | Program Manager | Product | Data | Analyst

projects.description:
üöú Excited to share my new project: Predicting Bulldozer Sale Prices with Machine Learning! üöú

In this project, I tackled a time series regression problem to predict the future sale prices of bulldozers based on historical auction data. The project is built on the Kaggle Bluebook for Bulldozers dataset, where I applied various machine learning techniques to optimize predictions.

üîç Project Overview:
Goal: Predict future sale prices of bulldozers using features such as sale date, machine ID, year made, and other machine-specific attributes.
Dataset: Kaggle‚Äôs Bluebook for Bulldozers dataset, containing historical auction prices with features like sale dates and machine specifications.

üîë Key Steps:
Data Cleaning & Preprocessing: Managed missing values and transformed categorical features into numerical categories using pandas.
Feature Engineering: Extracted date-related features (year, month, day) from the sale date to enhance model performance for time series data.
Modeling: Trained a Random Forest Regressor using a train/validation split to avoid data leakage.
Hyperparameter Tuning: Used GridSearchCV to fine-tune hyperparameters and improve model accuracy.
Evaluation: The model was evaluated using metrics like Root Mean Squared Logarithmic Error (RMSLE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and R-squared.

üìä Results:
Achieved an impressive RMSLE score of 0.26 on the validation set.
Key features like "YearMade" and "saledate" proved to be highly influential in the final predictions.

üí° Technologies Used:
Python: pandas, NumPy, scikit-learn
Modeling: Random Forest Regressor
Data Visualization: matplotlib, seaborn

üìÇ Check out the full project and code on GitHub https://lnkd.in/dXvVdJeC


hashtag#MachineLearning hashtag#DataScience hashtag#Regression hashtag#TimeSeries hashtag#Python hashtag#RandomForest hashtag#Kaggle hashtag#DataScienceProjects
projects.title: Predicting Bulldozer Sale Prices with Machine Learning - Time Series

member.occupation: MSQM @ NYU Stern | GC MS&E @ Stanford | Ex-Engineer @ Schlumberger (SLB) | PMO | Program Manager | Product | Data | Analyst

projects.description:
Project Overview
This project implements a machine learning pipeline to predict whether a patient has heart disease based on clinical features. Using models such as Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Random Forest classifiers, we aim for high accuracy in predictions, leveraging the UCI Heart Disease dataset.

üîç Problem Definition
Can we predict heart disease based on medical attributes?

üìä Dataset
The dataset consists of 14 clinical attributes, including:
Age: Patient's age in years
Sex: Gender (0 = Female, 1 = Male)
Chest Pain Type (cp): Categorical indicator
Cholesterol Levels (chol): Serum cholesterol
Maximum Heart Rate (thalach): Max heart rate achieved
Fasting Blood Sugar (fbs): Blood sugar levels

üîß Models Used
Logistic Regression
K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN)
Random Forest Classifier

üîß Steps Involved
Data Cleaning and EDA: Analyze missing values and correlations, with visualizations.
Model Building: Construct models and tune hyperparameters using GridSearchCV and RandomizedSearchCV, applying cross-validation for evaluation.
Model Evaluation: Metrics include Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-Score, ROC Curve, and AUC.
Model Comparison: Comparative analysis using metrics and visualizations.

üìà Results
Best Model: Logistic Regression achieved 88.52% accuracy.
Hyperparameter Tuning: Improved Random Forest accuracy from 83% to 86%.

üìâ Visualizations
Included ROC Curve, Precision-Recall Curve, and Confusion Matrix to assess performance, along with feature importance visualizations.

üõ†Ô∏è Tools
Python Libraries: pandas, NumPy, matplotlib, seaborn, scikit-learn

üìå Conclusion
Logistic Regression proved most effective, with potential for further improvement through more complex models or feature engineering.

üîó How to Run
Clone the repository.
projects.title: Heart Disease Prediction using Machine Learning

member.occupation: MSQM @ NYU Stern | GC MS&E @ Stanford | Ex-Engineer @ Schlumberger (SLB) | PMO | Program Manager | Product | Data | Analyst

projects.description:
üöÄ Project Overview
This project leverages unsupervised machine learning techniques, particularly K-Means clustering, to segment credit card customers based on their transaction patterns and financial behavior. The primary goal is to provide actionable insights for financial institutions like Capital One, Chase, or any other bank offering credit card products. These insights enable better decision-making for targeted marketing, credit risk assessment, product customization, and customer retention strategies.

By analyzing historical customer data, we can group customers into meaningful clusters, offering banks the ability to tailor their offerings and optimize profitability while managing risks effectively.

üßë‚Äçüíª Key Features
Data-Driven Segmentation: Cluster customers into distinct behavioral groups based on transaction frequency, credit limit usage, balance, and purchase types (one-off vs. installments).
Actionable Insights: Provide a basis for strategic decisions, such as identifying high-value customers, reducing credit default risks, or crafting customized credit card products.
Comprehensive Analysis: Visualizations and statistical summaries to explore patterns across clusters and compare financial metrics.
Scalable Model: The clustering model is flexible, making it adaptable for other financial datasets with similar features.

üìä Cluster Summary
These clusters represent various customer personas, such as:

Cluster 0: High balance, frequent cash advances, and moderate spending. Likely to benefit from a low-interest rate card or cash advance offers.
Cluster 1: Low spenders with limited credit usage, ideal for starter credit cards with minimal rewards.
Cluster 2: High spenders with frequent purchases, suitable for premium rewards programs and exclusive perks.
Cluster 3: Moderate users with some installment purchases, best suited for budget-friendly cards or installment plans.
projects.title: Credit Card Customer Clustering for Enhanced Product Insights

projects.description:
Surface modification of CNTs was done by attaching different functional groups (-OH, -COOH, -NH2) on CNTs through chemical route in order to obtain homogenous dispersion and stronger chemical bonds in the composites. Afterwards nanocomposites were prepared using CNTs as reinforcement and Epoxy (DGEBA) as resin improving their properties. 
Research paper got acceptance from Junior-Euromat Conference at Switzerland, 2012
projects.title: POLYMER BASED NANOCOMPOSITES REINFOIRCED WITH MULTI  WALLED CARBON NANOTUBES

After a detailed study and materialist analysis of the piezoelectric materials a prototype of a piezoelectric shoe was made which could charge a 3V battery after a walk of just one minute.

üöÄ Excited to Share My First Fully Interactive Tableau Dashboard! üìäüéâ

As part of MSQM Data Visualization course at NYU Stern School of Business, enjoyed the challenge of creating an interactive dashboard that provides a deep dive into Adidas' United States sales performance.
